bibl.title: Letter from Jesse W. Lazear to Charlotte C. Sweitzer, May 30, 1890

div1.p: Lazear writes that he has begun dissection work in his anatomy course. He describes his living arrangements and customs regarding women.

div1.head: Letter from Jesse W. Lazear to Charlotte C. Sweitzer, May 30, 1890
div1.p:
You see I have reached
my destination. Our steamer got to
Moville at 10 A.M. on Wednesday and
reached Glasgow at 11.P.M. We
stayed at Glasgow over night and
came over to Edinburgh yesterday
morning. Yesterday afternoon we called
at the University and made our
arrangements, and to-day we went
regularly to work. I have been
dissecting all afternoon.

The University buildings are very fine.
I will tell you more about them
later on.

The trip along the north coast of Ireland
and up the Clyde was magnificent.
The beauty of the scenery was much
beyond what I had expected. There
were bold headlands with sometimes
a green slope. I shall not attempt
to describe it at all. Throughout the
whole day this grand panorama lasted.
When we reached Glasgow at 11 P.M. it
was just getting dusk. I have not yet
had time to see much of Edinburgh. It is
certainly a very odd old town, but I am
getting used to the foreign ways already.
The girls here all have a very peculiar
ruddy complexion, and they are all
rather robust. Woman do all sorts
of heavy work, they actually carried
one of our trunks upstairs as though
they were used to that sort of thing
Women walk through the streets delivering
milk; they wear short dresses and have
their arms bare. We see men
dressed in plaid and kilts quite often
and Scotch caps are very often seen.
It is very cold and has been raining
off and on ever since I got here.
The arrangement here at Mrs Magills
is not just what we expected She
has given us a large front room
on the second story one end
of which is screened off for a bed-
room for Norris and Nicoll while
Waring and I occupy a room in
the third story. We have our meals
together in the large second story room.
The rest of the boys seem entirely
satisfied with the arrangement.
But I am not used to having any one
else in the room and I think I shall
withdraw from the arrangement in a
few days. I can get a room to myself
easily in some other house. I think
I can do better by myself than with
the party. Mrs. Magill gives us a very good
table.

I have met several of the demon-
strators at the University and they
are very kind to us. One of them, to
whom Norris had a letter showed
us around the Anatomy department
and told us how to find the matricula-
tion office and everything, and offered
to give us any information we
wanted about things outside the
University. I have not told you
how glad I was to get your letter
and paper when I arrived. I found
them lying on my table, and I sat
right down and read them. The feeling
of having been out of communication
with the world for eleven days is very
peculiar, I cannot realize that,
the world has gone on as usual during
that time. We seem to commence
just where we left off on the 17th of
May. I know I have forgotten lots of things
that I wanted to say, but I will say them again.
